required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: What Are the Three Dimensional Soft Tissue Changes That Occur After Orthognathic Surgery for Skeletal Class II Patients? Pre-test Post-test Quasi Experimental Study
clinical_study.official_title: What Are the Three Dimensional Soft Tissue Changes That Occur After Orthognathic Surgery for Skeletal Class II Patients? Pre-test Post-test Quasi Experimental Study

brief_summary.textblock: the aim of the study is to establish reference data that could be used for the creation of more accurate three dimensional prediction of soft tissue outcome.

detailed_description.textblock: in this study, 15 skeletal class 2 orthognathic patients will be selected. CBCT and proface will be done preoperatively. after the surgery and 6 months later the imaging investigations will be repeated to investigate the soft tissue changes that have resulted due to the bone movement.

primary_outcome.description: the changes that have occurred in the soft tissue of the face after undergoing orthognathic surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of soft tissue change to hard tissue change
secondary_outcome.description: the distance that the soft tissue has moved compared to the underlying bone, as a percentage.

secondary_outcome.measure: Is the esthetic outcome as expected/imagined?
secondary_outcome.description: using a 100mm visual analogue scale the patient will be asked to score how the aesthetic outcome measured against his expectations. 0mm is the worst score where the changes havent met the expectations at all and 100mm is where the outcome has perfectly met the expectation.
the changes that have occurred in the soft tissue of the face after undergoing orthognathic surgery
the changes that have occurred in the soft tissue of the face after undergoing orthognathic surgery

study_pop.textblock: patients with class 2 skeletal deformity, over 18 years and younger than 40

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with class II skeletal deformity
- Patients must be over 18 years of age to allow for growth cessation
- Patients must not have any systemic condition which contraindicates general anaesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- o patients with cleft palate
- patients with syndromes affecting their craniofacial structure
- patients with facial scars
- patients with severe facial asymmetry
